articles.title: My mission to make life more user friendly for the disability community
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 09 February 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-026-00389-zInventor Josh Miele says that accelerating change requires uprooting social attitudes about blindness and other disabilities.
articles.content:
Josh Miele explains the nuances of a tactile map of a Bay Area Rapid Transit station.Credit: Laurie Udesky

Working scientist profiles This article is part of an occasional series in which Nature profiles scientists with unusual career histories or outside interests.

Fifty-seven-year-old Josh Miele is a blind scientist, an inventor of adaptive technology and a 2021 MacArthur Foundation ‘genius’ fellow. In the 1990s, as an undergraduate and graduate student at the University of California, Berkeley (UCB) — before the invention of GPS — Miele could be seen around town climbing up street signs and feeling the embossed letters to work out which street he was on when travelling in unfamiliar areas, all to the surprise of bystanders. “Some accessibility is just about getting things done, and some accessibility is about teaching others about how much of a pain in the neck it is to get things done,” says Miele.

Structural biology for researchers with low vision

Miele was nurtured by his mother from a young age to buck the system. In his 2025 memoir, Connecting the Dots, he recounts a visit to an art museum, during which his mother urged him to get up close to a sculpture and “feel it with his hands”.

As he did so, he was mortified to hear his mother berating the museum staff for trying to deprive him of the hands-on experience. It was one of many instances of his mother making him “practise breaking the rules, thinking about when they needed to be broken and practising being visible, all of which are essential for me now”, says Miele, a polymath whose pursuits have included physics and space-science studies, working on a Mars probe and doctoral work on the psychology of sound perception. All of which would set him up for a career in designing accessible technology. Miele met a reporter from Nature’s careers team at his neat, compact woodworking studio in Berkeley, where he goes “to get out of his head”, carving chopstick holders and other things.

Outspoken start

Miele wasn’t born blind — a neighbour attacked him with acid when he was four years old, blinding and badly burning him. He reflects in his memoir that his young age probably protected his outlook: “I had a life to enjoy, and I couldn’t let being blind and burned prevent it.”

Instead, the incident forced him to begin engineering the world around him in his neighbourhood of Brooklyn, New York City, to make it work for him. He felt around his home to map it out, built a map of his neighbourhood in his mind and took apart radios and household appliances to understand how they worked. Miele used the echo of the sound his roller skates made to help him steer clear of objects that he might crash into while zooming down the pavement in front of his family’s house. At age 12, with a friend’s mother dictating instructions, he coded his first computer program, commanding an early home computer to count on screen from one to ten. In secondary school, inspired by the 1983 film WarGames “about a computer hacker guy with a talking computer” and with the help of his Braille teacher, Miele set up a speech synthesizer as a rudimentary screen reader on his home computer.

Several years later, during his physics undergraduate degree, he helped to update the features of outSPOKEN, a software for people with low vision or who are blind that reads aloud what is displayed on a computer’s graphical user interface. The Mac version was originally released in 1989 by Berkeley Systems, a small, local software company.

Miele got the job through his connection with Marc Sutton, whom he describes as “a laid-back blind hippie”. They met in The Cave, the basement of a UCB library in which blind students congregated to use Braille machines and other accessible equipment, talk about disability rights and learn from each other. Miele says that students worked and played hard at all hours in The Cave.

Working Scientist career profiles

His interactions with The Cave cohort and the wider disability-rights community marked a turning point for Miele. Before UCB, he says, “I didn’t think of myself as being part of a disability community. Why would I?” There weren’t any positive portrayals of blind and disabled people, in general, he says. With his new-found peers, he quickly realized that “we all deal with other people telling us that we can’t do stuff, building things that we can’t use and marginalizing us intentionally or unintentionally”.

A long-term friend and colleague of Miele’s who is also blind, UCB English professor Georgina Kleege, says that outSPOKEN was the first screen reader she ever used — although she didn’t know Miele at the time. “It changed my life. It made my life possible, because it meant I could use a computer,” she says.

In 1993, Miele pursued an internship at NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland, indulging his childhood interest in rockets and outer space. There, he helped to develop software to calibrate optical sensors aboard the Mars Observer probe that launched in 1992. But the spacecraft disappeared before it entered Mars’ orbit.

Deeply disheartened, Miele felt like physics was no longer the right place for him. Once back in Berkeley, he realized that building accessible technologies “was probably the most value I could add”, he says. “I knew that it would be fun. I knew it would be interesting. I knew that there was plenty of work to do.” So, he put his undergraduate studies on hold to work full time at Berkeley Systems.

Quick-fire Q&A Josh Miele enjoys playing music.Credit: 2016 Barbara Butkus Why did it take 10 years for you to finish your undergraduate degree? Because I find classwork really unsatisfying. I am motivated by doing things that make a difference in people’s lives. I’m always thinking about problems that people with disabilities have and I learn about new technologies as they come along. Sometimes things come to me in the shower. Who are your greatest influences and mentors? My stepfather, a geophysicist, was one. He was incredible at explaining things to me. For example, when I was young, he laid out two ropes on a table for me to feel to explain the difference between the wave height and wave density of AM and FM radio frequencies. Science-fiction writer Ursula Le Guin is another, because she wrote and thought about people in unusual ways. And she’s a master of the pencil sketch with words. What drew you to playing guitar and being in a band when you were younger? I love music and enjoy performing. And I wanted to be cool. As young kids, aged 13–14 years, we formed a band called Child Labor. It was a play on ‘Men at Work’, a group that was popular at the time.

A fresh direction

Eventually, Miele realized that he needed to return to UCB to finish his bachelor’s degree and did so in 1997. He’d already completed his physics requirements and spent his last semester taking courses in music appreciation, disability studies and psychology.

In 1998, he began his PhD in psychoacoustics and cognitive psychology at UCB. “I wanted to study ways of using non-speech sounds, including 3D immersive audio, to present information for screen-reader users, to speed up those interactions,” he says. For instance, he explains, imagine a screen reader reading out information in the top-left cell of a spreadsheet or table and it sounding like the voice was coming from the left and above the user. “It’s more efficient and intuitive than having the speech say ‘top-left cell’,” he says.

That same year, he started an internship at the Smith-Kettlewell Eye Research Institute in San Francisco, California. There, he worked on the data-analysis software MATLAB, to make it accessible to blind people. His Smith-Kettlewell stint evolved into a 19-year relationship, both during and after his PhD.

The institute’s environment “was incredibly flexible and accommodating”, says Miele. “It was also one of the few research institutions in the world that valued the kind of accessibility technology research programme that I wanted to build.” His proudest work included developing a way for blind and partially sighted people to print embossed, or raised, tactile street maps for any US location — to get a full picture of a neighbourhood or address through their fingers. Miele started the project, called tactile map automated production (TMAP), in 2003 as a postdoc at Smith-Kettlewell.

For it, he repurposed coding that he had developed for his graduate work, which enabled him to print research charts and graphs in Braille. He applied the program to data from geographical information systems (GIS) freely available through the US Census Bureau. Other people had used GIS to create tactile maps, Miele explains, but these required visual interfaces. “They were sighted people making maps for blind people.”

Josh Miele (standing) teaches a participant at a Blind Arduino Project workshop; he launched this series of maker gatherings in 2015.Credit: Jean Miele 2026

TMAP enabled blind people to create a Braille printable map at the scale and location of their choice and on their own. “This revolutionized the availability of tactile street maps for blind travelers,” noted a Smith-Kettlewell announcement in September 2021 (see go.nature.com/3zabzja).

Steve Landau is a close friend and frequent collaborator of Miele’s and the founder and president of Touch Graphics, an accessibility technology company in Newark, Delaware. The firm specializes in products that convey spatial information through touch. He has wrestled with Miele over the usability of the firm’s assistive technologies. Landau says that Miele can be blunt and has frequently “burst his bubble”, explaining why something he proposed won’t work.

These tools help visually impaired scientists read data and journals

Landau worked with Miele on creating a digital version of TMAP known as the Talking Tactile Tablet (TTT). One disagreement centred on how people would use screen touching on the tablet. As a sighted person, Landau explains, he was overlooking the complex ways in which blind people swipe and rotate their fingers on surfaces. “I needed to be schooled to make the device as intuitive as possible.”

The TTT enabled users to print an embossed map to overlay the tablet’s screen. Then, by tapping a map area, the tablet would spit out spoken information, such as street names, the number of traffic lanes, the direction of traffic and the location of pedestrian crossings. The handheld tablet worked well even for people who don’t know Braille, Landau explains.

His innovations empower a broad community by enabling independence and better navigation, representing meaningful social progress and inclusion. articles.personality_title: Inventor Josh Miele creates tools that help blind people explore the world by touch and sound
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Josh Miele is a blind scientist and inventor who has spent years developing technology to help people with vision loss. He was blinded as a child and learned early on to find new ways to navigate and understand his surroundings.

**What happened** – Miele created a system called Tactile Map Automated Production (TMAP) that allows blind people to print and use raised, touchable maps of any US neighborhood. He also helped develop the Talking Tactile Tablet (TTT), which reads out information when users touch different parts of a raised map on the tablet screen. These tools give blind users more independence in exploring places.

**Impact** – Before Miele’s work, tactile maps were made by sighted people and often required assistance. His technology lets blind users create and use maps themselves, making travel and navigation easier and more accessible. The TTT also helps people who don’t read Braille get detailed information through sound, opening access to more users.

**What's next step** – Miele continues to improve these tools and hopes they will be widely available to help more blind and visually impaired people. His work encourages designers to think carefully about how blind users interact with technology, leading to better products in the future.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Josh Miele’s inventions use touch and sound to give blind people new ways to understand and navigate the world around them.
articles.personality_title_fr: Josh Miele invente des outils qui aident les aveugles à explorer le monde par le toucher et le son
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Josh Miele est un scientifique aveugle et inventeur qui a passé des années à développer des technologies pour aider les personnes malvoyantes. Il a perdu la vue enfant et a appris tôt à trouver de nouvelles façons de se repérer et de comprendre son environnement.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Miele a créé un système appelé Production automatisée de cartes tactiles (TMAP) qui permet aux aveugles d’imprimer et d’utiliser des cartes en relief de n’importe quel quartier aux États-Unis. Il a aussi aidé à développer la Tablette tactile parlante (TTT), qui lit à voix haute les informations lorsque l’utilisateur touche différentes parties d’une carte en relief sur l’écran. Ces outils donnent plus d’autonomie aux utilisateurs aveugles.

**Impact** – Avant le travail de Miele, les cartes tactiles étaient faites par des personnes voyantes et nécessitaient souvent de l’aide. Sa technologie permet aux aveugles de créer et d’utiliser eux-mêmes leurs cartes, facilitant ainsi leurs déplacements. La TTT aide aussi les personnes ne lisant pas le braille à obtenir des informations détaillées grâce au son, ce qui élargit le nombre d’utilisateurs.

**Prochaine étape** – Miele continue d’améliorer ces outils et espère qu’ils seront largement disponibles pour aider plus de personnes malvoyantes. Son travail encourage les concepteurs à penser attentivement à la façon dont les aveugles utilisent la technologie, ce qui conduira à de meilleurs produits à l’avenir.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les inventions de Josh Miele utilisent le toucher et le son pour offrir aux aveugles de nouvelles façons de comprendre et de se déplacer dans le monde qui les entoure.
articles.personality_title_es: Josh Miele crea herramientas que ayudan a personas ciegas a explorar el mundo con el tacto y el sonido
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Josh Miele es un científico e inventor ciego que ha dedicado años a desarrollar tecnologías para ayudar a personas con pérdida de visión. Perdió la vista cuando era niño y aprendió temprano a encontrar nuevas formas de orientarse y entender su entorno.

**Qué pasó** – Miele creó un sistema llamado Producción Automatizada de Mapas Táctiles (TMAP) que permite a personas ciegas imprimir y usar mapas en relieve de cualquier barrio en Estados Unidos. También ayudó a desarrollar la Tableta Táctil Hablante (TTT), que lee en voz alta la información cuando el usuario toca diferentes partes de un mapa en relieve en la pantalla. Estas herramientas dan más independencia a los usuarios ciegos.

**Impacto** – Antes del trabajo de Miele, los mapas táctiles eran hechos por personas videntes y a menudo requerían ayuda. Su tecnología permite a las personas ciegas crear y usar sus propios mapas, facilitando sus desplazamientos. La TTT también ayuda a quienes no leen braille a obtener información detallada mediante el sonido, ampliando el número de usuarios.

**Próximo paso** – Miele sigue mejorando estas herramientas y espera que estén disponibles para ayudar a más personas con discapacidad visual. Su trabajo impulsa a los diseñadores a pensar en cómo las personas ciegas interactúan con la tecnología, lo que llevará a mejores productos en el futuro.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Las invenciones de Josh Miele usan el tacto y el sonido para ofrecer nuevas formas a las personas ciegas de entender y moverse por el mundo que los rodea.

articles.title: Press release - MEPs adopt proposals to tackle Europe’s housing crisis
articles.summary: On Monday, the Housing Committee adopted its final recommendations on the housing crisis in the EU, proposing solutions for decent, sustainable and affordable housing.Special Committee on the Housing Crisis in the European Union Source : © European Union, 2026 - EP
articles.content:
In its final report, adopted with 23 votes in favour, 6 votes against, and 4 abstentions, Parliament’s Special Committee on the Housing Crisis emphasises that millions of Europeans face precarious living conditions due to the housing crisis and calls for EU legislation to address the viability and cost of building new housing.



Improving living standards



To ensure decent housing, MEPs want specific earmarks of the funds included in the Commission’s Affordable Housing Plan to improve the energy performance of the residential buildings and to combat energy poverty. All new dwellings should meet quality standards on insulation, energy-efficiency, and air quality, MEPs say.

To improve living standards in overcrowded cities, MEPs want the upcoming law on short term rentals to strike a balance between facilitating tourism and housing affordability to ensure the proliferation of short-term rentals does not threaten affordability in cities.

MEPs also want an adequate share of public and social housing in EU cities to increase the affordability and supply of housing for vulnerable people.



Investments and fiscal aid

MEPs urge member states to introduce incentive-based tax systems to support low- and middle-income households, remove tax barriers (i.e. high registration fees) for first time buyers, and make long-term rentals more affordable.

The report calls for more EU investment in housing by better coordinating existing funding and by reallocating unused Recovery and Resilience Plan resources to support the construction and renovation of social, public cooperative, and affordable housing.

MEPs also say any revision of state aid rules should facilitate public investment in social housing, while respecting the diversity of national markets.



Faster and easier procedures

MEPs want the Commission to propose a housing simplification package to reduce red tape in the housing sector. They want simpler permitting procedures, for example through digital permit-granting procedures, and a deadline of 60 days when permits relate to sustainable and affordable housing proposals.



Industrial sovereignty in the construction and renovation sector

The EU must enhance its industrial sovereignty in the construction and renovation sector, MEPs say, urging the Commission to scale up innovative and sustainable products, reinforce the single market for raw materials, and include minimum ‘Made in EU’ origin requirements for components in EU co-financed projects.

Finally, MEPs want the upcoming European strategy for housing construction to focus on improving the working conditions of skilled workers through training and fair wages. They call for easier intra-EU labour mobility, improved mutual recognition of professional qualifications and, where necessary, the recruitment of skilled workers from third countries.



Quotes

Rapporteur of the housing report, Borja Giménez Larraz (EPP, ES), said: “The adoption of this report by the Housing Committee marks a significant step forward for the European Parliament. It reflects a broad and responsible consensus across political groups, grounded in pragmatism rather than ideology. The report places housing supply at the core of the response, recognising the need to enable the delivery of around 10 million additional homes across Europe. It also highlights the urgent need to support families and young people, who are bearing the brunt of the housing crisis. This balanced approach strengthens private property, provides legal certainty, creates the right framework for investment, and respects the diversity of national housing systems, while contributing to more affordable housing across Europe”.

Chair of the Housing committee, Irene Tinagli (S&D, IT), said: “Today’s strong endorsement of the report sends a clear message: we are ready to address housing as a social priority, strengthening cooperation between European, national and local authorities to tackle the crisis at its roots. The report sets out concrete measures across all dimensions of the housing challenge, including mobilising greater investment through EU, national and private funds, improving the quality, sustainability and habitability of homes, and addressing labour shortages and competitiveness in the construction sector. It reflects months of work and consultation by the Special Committee on the Housing Crisis, which will continue to monitor upcoming proposals and legislation to ensure that citizens’ interests remain at the core”.



Media briefing

On Tuesday at 17.00, Chair of the HOUS Committee Irene Tinagli (S&D, IT) and rapporteur Borja Giménez Larraz (EPP, ES) will participate in a media briefing in Strasbourg to discuss the report and answer questions from journalists. More details about the briefing here.



Background

On 18 December 2024, Parliament established a Special Committee on the Housing Crisis in the European Union to put forward solutions for decent, sustainable, and affordable housing for all EU citizens. It has been tasked with mapping housing needs, analysing existing housing policies across the EU and contributing to the future implementation of the EU’s affordable housing plan.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the European Parliament's adoption of comprehensive proposals to address the housing crisis affecting millions of Europeans. The measures aim to improve housing affordability, sustainability, and quality, with significant social impact across the EU. The detailed recommendations and planned legislative actions indicate a meaningful and broad effort to improve living conditions and social equity, fulfilling the criteria for inspiring good news.
articles.personality_title: European Parliament adopts new plans to tackle housing crisis
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Millions of people in Europe struggle to find affordable and decent homes. To address this, the European Parliament created a special committee in December 2024 to study the housing crisis and suggest solutions.

**What happened** – On Monday, the Parliament's Housing Committee approved a report with recommendations to improve housing across the EU. The report was supported by 23 members, with 6 against and 4 abstaining. It calls for laws to make building new homes easier and cheaper, improve energy efficiency, and increase social housing.

**Impact** – This report is important because it offers clear steps to help families and young people who find it hard to afford homes. It pushes for better rules to reduce paperwork when building houses and suggests tax changes to help low- and middle-income buyers. The plan also supports making homes more energy efficient and improving workers’ conditions in construction.

**What's next step** – The European Commission will work on new laws based on these recommendations. The Parliament will keep watching to make sure these ideas turn into action, aiming to build about 10 million new homes and improve housing quality across Europe.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The European Parliament set out detailed plans to make housing more affordable, sustainable, and accessible for millions of Europeans facing tough living conditions.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Parlement européen adopte de nouvelles mesures pour lutter contre la crise du logement
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Des millions de personnes en Europe ont du mal à trouver des logements abordables et décents. Pour y remédier, le Parlement européen a créé en décembre 2024 un comité spécial chargé d’étudier la crise du logement et de proposer des solutions.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Lundi, la commission du logement du Parlement a approuvé un rapport contenant des recommandations pour améliorer le logement dans l’UE. Le rapport a été soutenu par 23 membres, avec 6 contre et 4 abstentions. Il demande des lois pour faciliter et réduire le coût de la construction de nouveaux logements, améliorer l'efficacité énergétique et augmenter le logement social.

**Impact** – Ce rapport est important car il propose des mesures claires pour aider les familles et les jeunes qui ont du mal à se loger. Il encourage des règles pour réduire les formalités administratives lors de la construction, et suggère des changements fiscaux pour aider les acheteurs à revenus faibles et moyens. Le plan soutient aussi l’amélioration de l’efficacité énergétique des logements et des conditions de travail dans la construction.

**Prochaine étape** – La Commission européenne travaillera sur de nouvelles lois basées sur ces recommandations. Le Parlement continuera de suivre pour s’assurer que ces idées deviennent réalité, avec pour objectif la construction d’environ 10 millions de nouveaux logements et l’amélioration de la qualité du logement en Europe.

**En une phrase** – Le Parlement européen a défini des plans détaillés pour rendre le logement plus abordable, durable et accessible aux millions d’Européens confrontés à des conditions de vie difficiles.
articles.personality_title_es: El Parlamento Europeo aprueba nuevos planes para abordar la crisis de vivienda
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Millones de personas en Europa tienen dificultades para encontrar viviendas asequibles y dignas. Para solucionar esto, el Parlamento Europeo creó un comité especial en diciembre de 2024 para estudiar la crisis de vivienda y proponer soluciones.

**Qué pasó** – El lunes, el Comité de Vivienda del Parlamento aprobó un informe con recomendaciones para mejorar la vivienda en la UE. El informe fue apoyado por 23 miembros, con 6 en contra y 4 abstenciones. Pide leyes que faciliten y abaraten la construcción de nuevas viviendas, mejoren la eficiencia energética y aumenten la vivienda social.

**Impacto** – Este informe es importante porque ofrece pasos claros para ayudar a familias y jóvenes que tienen dificultades para pagar una casa. Propone reglas para reducir trámites al construir viviendas y sugiere cambios fiscales para apoyar a compradores con ingresos bajos y medios. También apoya mejorar la eficiencia energética y las condiciones laborales en la construcción.

**Próximo paso** – La Comisión Europea trabajará en nuevas leyes basadas en estas recomendaciones. El Parlamento seguirá supervisando para asegurar que estas ideas se conviertan en acción, con el objetivo de construir alrededor de 10 millones de nuevas viviendas y mejorar la calidad de la vivienda en Europa.

**Una frase clave** – El Parlamento Europeo estableció planes detallados para hacer la vivienda más asequible, sostenible y accesible para millones de europeos que enfrentan condiciones de vida difíciles.
articles.image_prompt: A harmonious cluster of stylized, warm-toned European city buildings with open windows glowing softly, interconnected by gently rising scaffolding and cranes shaped like supportive hands, surrounded by abstract figures of diverse homes—social, public, and cooperative—nestled together under a calm sky, symbolizing collaborative effort, sustainable construction, and affordable housing for all.

articles.title: 'Inequality: Deliberative democracy collectively chooses policies to create a better society'
articles.summary: Imagine designing a society without knowing your role in it. Would you still choose the inequality we live with today? Eve Irvine welcomes Kate Pickett, Author and Professor of Epidemiology at the University of York. Her work as a social epidemiologist concludes that inequality is not just unfair, it has real-life, even deadly, consequences. It erodes trust, wellbeing, education, and even the length of our lives. We already have the answers. What we lack is the will to act. This book, The Good Society, is a call to collective courage, to choose policies that prioritize human flourishing, over GDP, a focus on designing equity.
articles.content:
Imagine designing a society without knowing your role in it. Would you still choose the inequality we live with today? Eve Irvine welcomes Kate Pickett, Author and Professor of Epidemiology at the University of York. Her work as a social epidemiologist concludes that inequality is not just unfair, it has real-life, even deadly, consequences. It erodes trust, wellbeing, education, and even the length of our lives. We already have the answers. What we lack is the will to act. This book, The Good Society, is a call to collective courage, to choose policies that prioritize human flourishing, over GDP, a focus on designing equity.

Video by: Eve IRVINE

articles.reasoning: The article highlights the significant societal issue of inequality, emphasizing its harmful real-life consequences and advocating for collective action and policy change to promote equity and human flourishing. It addresses a broad, meaningful topic with substantial context and a call to action, inspiring hope for a better society.
articles.personality_title: Choosing a fairer society: New ideas to reduce inequality
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Inequality means that some people have much more money, education, and opportunities than others. This difference can affect trust, happiness, and even how long people live.

**What happened** – Kate Pickett, a professor and author from the University of York, shared her research showing that inequality is not only unfair but also harmful to society. She wrote a book called "The Good Society," which asks people to imagine creating a society without knowing their own place in it. Would they still accept the current levels of inequality? She argues that we already know what needs to be done, but we need the courage to make changes.

**Impact** – This message is important because it connects inequality to real problems like poor health and less trust between people. It moves the conversation beyond just money to how society can be better for everyone. It encourages people to think about fairness and choose policies that help all people thrive, not just grow the economy.

**What's next step** – The next step is to use these ideas to guide decision-making in communities and governments. By focusing on fairness and human wellbeing, policies can be designed to reduce inequality and improve life for many.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Kate Pickett’s research and book encourage us to work together to build a society where fairness and well-being come before wealth alone.
articles.personality_title_fr: Choisir une société plus juste : de nouvelles idées pour réduire les inégalités
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les inégalités signifient que certaines personnes ont beaucoup plus d'argent, d'éducation et d'opportunités que d'autres. Cette différence peut affecter la confiance, le bonheur et même la durée de vie.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Kate Pickett, professeure et auteure à l'Université de York, a partagé ses recherches montrant que l'inégalité n'est pas seulement injuste, mais aussi nuisible à la société. Elle a écrit un livre intitulé « La bonne société », qui invite à imaginer la création d'une société sans connaître sa place. Accepterait-on encore les inégalités actuelles ? Elle affirme que nous savons déjà quoi faire, mais qu'il faut du courage pour agir.

**Impact** – Ce message est important car il relie les inégalités à de vrais problèmes comme la mauvaise santé et la perte de confiance entre les gens. Il pousse la réflexion au-delà de l'argent, vers une société meilleure pour tous. Il encourage à penser à l'équité et à choisir des politiques qui aident tout le monde.

**Prochaine étape** – L'étape suivante est d'utiliser ces idées pour guider les décisions dans les communautés et les gouvernements. En se concentrant sur l'équité et le bien-être humain, les politiques peuvent réduire les inégalités et améliorer la vie de beaucoup.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les recherches et le livre de Kate Pickett nous encouragent à construire ensemble une société où l'équité et le bien-être priment sur la richesse.
articles.personality_title_es: Elegir una sociedad más justa: nuevas ideas para reducir la desigualdad
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La desigualdad significa que algunas personas tienen mucho más dinero, educación y oportunidades que otras. Esta diferencia puede afectar la confianza, la felicidad e incluso la duración de la vida.

**Qué pasó** – Kate Pickett, profesora y autora de la Universidad de York, compartió su investigación que muestra que la desigualdad no solo es injusta, sino también dañina para la sociedad. Escribió un libro llamado "La buena sociedad", que invita a imaginar una sociedad sin conocer el propio lugar en ella. ¿Aún aceptaríamos los niveles actuales de desigualdad? Ella dice que ya sabemos qué hacer, pero necesitamos valor para actuar.

Lleva la conversación más allá del dinero para pensar en cómo la sociedad puede ser mejor para todos. Anima a pensar en la justicia y a elegir políticas que ayuden a todos a prosperar.

**Próximo paso** – El siguiente paso es usar estas ideas para guiar las decisiones en comunidades y gobiernos. Al enfocarse en la justicia y el bienestar humano, las políticas pueden reducir la desigualdad y mejorar la vida de muchas personas.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La investigación y el libro de Kate Pickett nos invitan a trabajar juntos para construir una sociedad donde la justicia y el bienestar sean más importantes que solo la riqueza.

articles.title: Proposed amnesty law offers political prisoners in Venezuela an ‘opportunity’
articles.summary: A draft amnesty law in Venezuela aimed at granting immediate clemency to people jailed for participating in political protests or criticizing public figures, has been welcomed by a UN commission of experts – although they have emphasised the Venezuelan people need to be at the centre of the process.
articles.content: A draft amnesty law in Venezuela aimed at granting immediate clemency to people jailed for participating in political protests or criticizing public figures, has been welcomed by a UN commission of experts – although they have emphasised the Venezuelan people need to be at the centre of the process.

articles.reasoning: The draft amnesty law in Venezuela proposes immediate clemency for political prisoners, representing a significant potential advancement in human rights and justice for many citizens. The involvement and endorsement by a UN commission adds legitimacy and international support, highlighting the broad societal impact. While the law is still a proposal and emphasizes the need for public involvement, it addresses a meaningful issue with substantial positive implications for political freedom and justice.
articles.personality_title: Venezuela’s draft amnesty law offers new hope for political prisoners
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Venezuela has many people in jail because they took part in protests or spoke out against government leaders. These prisoners are often called political prisoners.

**What happened** – The Venezuelan government has created a draft law that could free these political prisoners quickly. This law is still a proposal, but it suggests granting immediate clemency, which means pardoning or letting these people go without waiting for long legal processes. A group of experts from the United Nations (UN) has welcomed this idea but said it is important that the people of Venezuela are involved in deciding how the law is used.

**Impact** – This draft law could help many people who have been jailed just for expressing their opinions or joining protests. It is important because it could improve human rights and fairness in Venezuela. The support from the UN experts adds trust and shows that the international community is paying attention. This law could change how political freedom works in the country.

**What’s next step** – The draft law still needs to be discussed and approved by Venezuela’s government and lawmakers. The Venezuelan people’s opinions will be key in shaping the final version. If passed, it may lead to the release of many political prisoners and could start a new chapter in Venezuela’s political life.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A new draft law in Venezuela aims to free political prisoners quickly, with support from the UN and an emphasis on involving the people in the process.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un projet de loi d'amnistie au Venezuela offre une nouvelle chance aux prisonniers politiques
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Au Venezuela, de nombreuses personnes sont en prison pour avoir participé à des manifestations ou critiqué des dirigeants. Ces détenus sont souvent appelés prisonniers politiques.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le gouvernement vénézuélien a proposé un projet de loi qui pourrait libérer rapidement ces prisonniers politiques. Cette loi est encore en discussion, mais elle prévoit une clémence immédiate, c’est-à-dire pardonner ou libérer ces personnes sans attendre de longs procès. Un groupe d’experts des Nations Unies (ONU) a salué cette idée, mais a souligné que le peuple vénézuélien doit être au centre de la décision.

**Impact** – Ce projet de loi pourrait aider beaucoup de personnes emprisonnées uniquement pour avoir exprimé leurs opinions ou participé à des manifestations. C’est important car cela pourrait améliorer les droits humains et la justice au Venezuela. Le soutien des experts de l’ONU apporte de la confiance et montre que la communauté internationale suit la situation. Cette loi pourrait changer la liberté politique dans le pays.

**Prochaine étape** – Le projet de loi doit encore être discuté et approuvé par le gouvernement et les législateurs vénézuéliens. L’avis du peuple sera essentiel pour définir la version finale. Si elle est adoptée, elle pourrait permettre la libération de nombreux prisonniers politiques et ouvrir un nouveau chapitre politique.

**Message clé en une phrase** – Un nouveau projet de loi au Venezuela vise à libérer rapidement les prisonniers politiques, avec le soutien de l’ONU et une forte participation du peuple.
articles.personality_title_es: Un proyecto de ley en Venezuela ofrece una nueva oportunidad a presos políticos

Es importante porque podría mejorar los derechos humanos y la justicia en Venezuela. El apoyo de los expertos de la ONU genera confianza y muestra que la comunidad internacional observa la situación. Esta ley podría cambiar la libertad política en el país.

**Próximo paso** – El proyecto de ley debe ser discutido y aprobado por el gobierno y los legisladores venezolanos. La opinión del pueblo será clave para definir la versión final. Si se aprueba, podría llevar a la liberación de muchos presos políticos y abrir un nuevo capítulo político.
